description: The paper's central prediction: BE must conform exactly (δ_B = 0). All-positive series coefficients in 1/(e^x − 1) = Σ e^(−kx) guarantee complete monotonicity via the Bernstein-Widder theorem. The minus sign in the denominator is forced by the constraint. [Paper §8.2–8.3]

Must show periodic deviation (δ_B > 0). Alternating-sign coefficients in 1/(e^x + 1) = Σ (−1)^(k+1) e^(−kx) violate complete monotonicity. The Pauli exclusion principle IS the deviation — the plus sign produces the alternating signs that prevent ε from vanishing. Deviation controlled by the Dirichlet eta function. [Paper §8.2–8.5]
Classical limit — single exponential e^(−x). Approximately Benford-conformant (|ε| bounded at ~0.03) but not exact. Lacks the infinite-sum structure that makes BE exact. [Paper §8.2]

Bosonic (photon) distribution — spectral radiance values derived from BE statistics. Tests the constraint on light itself: photons are massless bosons, so the distribution should inherit BE's conformance. Light = zero deviation = zero mass. [Paper §2.2, §8.3]
